channel.title: The God VS Satan religious debate
channel.description:
Original thread - http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,554181.40.html Purpose of this thread: there's just a few points I want to clear up which I can't do so in the previous thread for obvious reasons.
Quote from "Pink Phat", >God is more of a peaceful character, who created the world.
If we're talking about god of the bible here, god has killed millions more people than satan has. Satan killed 11 people, god killed millions directly or indirectly. Let's not forget the bible tells tales of god flooding the whole earth to start fresh (and look where that got us). But by all accounts in the bible god is not peaceful, take the story of the tower of babel for instance, a united man all speaking one language attempted to build a tower that would reach the heavens, god not wanted any of this gave different groups different languages so they could no longer cooperate. Whether or not you interpret this literally or not, it says something about gods character, he would rather divide (and conqueror) man rather than have man cooperate.
Quote from "heatrn11", >because you obviously don't understand the difference between God the father, God the son, and God the Holy spirit.
Would now be a good time to remind you that other people who read and follow the bible don't believe in the son or holy spirit? There's several thousand sects of christianity because people who read and follow the bible can't make up how the bible should be interpreted. Divine word of god? Then why can't the followers decide on what should be and what shouldn't be followed.
Quote from "heatrn11", >God loves, God wants everyone to come with him to heaven, and he gives everyone a choice to pick heaven or hell.
It's not a choice though, is it? Do as I say or face eternal damnation of unimaginable agony. That's like a rapist telling his victim "don't fight or I will stab you". I won't even bring up the idea of free will, either.
Quote from "heatrn11", >To tell you the reason why God hasn't proven himself to Earth, is that, God has actually revealed himself in the past.
But he hasn't. The bible is not proof that god has proven himself, the bible is the claim that requires the proof. The bible claims god flooded the earth and had 2 of every species of animal on one boat, this is demonstrably false on nearly every point. The bible claims that Jesus was born in nazareth, it has been shown through excavations that there is not and has never been a city on the site where nazareth is claimed to be. The bible claims plagues in Egypt (and was the bane of my childhood religious classes, seeing that I was interested in Egypt and knew that these claims were nothing more than fictional stories despite being 6), again this is demonstrably false as no evidence or historical records exist barring one book. There's dozens of other things in the bible that are contradictory or have been proven false, the only claims in the bible that can't be proven false are claims that can't be proven as well, such as the entity of god. A flying spaghetti monster or the pink unicorn or even a dragon in a garage all share the same properties as god, they cannot be proven and they cannot be proven. Just because you cannot disprove gods existence does not make the idea credible.
Quote from "heatrn11", >For a future question 'Who created God if God created everything?'. Simple answer God wasn't created he always was, always is and always will be.
Pure speculation on your part. To quote Carl Sagan, "In many cultures it is customary to answer that God created the universe out of nothing. But this is mere temporizing. If we wish courageously to pursue the question, we must, of course ask next where God comes from? And if we decide this to be unanswerable, why not save a step and conclude that the universe has always existed?".
Quote from "heatrn11", >Example, Hitler killed thousands of jews, what he did was wrong, but in his mind set he believe it to be right.
Hitler also said he believed he was doing gods work. Because of the nature of the statement, you really can't say that he wasn't.
Quote from "heatrn11", >So if the kitten was sick and the kitten was dieing, you'd be happy and I'd be in a state of depression.
Any sane human being who feels empathy wouldn't feel happy at the suffering of another. This isn't what you said but it is relevant, some very influential christians have publicly stated that the only reason they do not kill people is because the bible tells them it is wrong. I find such a position saddening, I do not need a creator of a universe personally telling me what is right and wrong, and I do not need threat of punishment to refrain from doing bad things. I feel empathy therefore I do not attempt to place another person in a position of suffering.
Quote from "heatrn11", >You can't try and criticize God if you Know close to nothing about his exists or how he thinks.
But we have the bible that states what god has done and we can criticise those actions. We can prove that a lot of claims in the bible are demonstrably wrong but it doesn't change the fact that the bible claims that this is how god acts. The bible claims he would rather flood the whole earth and kill all its inhabitants rather than attempt to fix the problems. The bible tells us that because a woman (who had no knowledge of right or wrong, I might add) who ate from a tree, god decided that all humans born are born into sin and must repent. I find the act of blaming people for actions that they were not responsible for and could not have possibility prevented absolutely morally corrupt.
Quote from "heatrn11", >Only an intelligent designer or creator rather, could put the universe together and make every single particle work with each other.
If you're going down the "intelligent design" route, could you perhaps explain some problems with the "intelligent design"? Such as humans having a near useless appendix which can burst requiring people to have them surgically removed. Such as people having wisdom teeth that serve no current purpose, which cause people unnecessary pain and also require the person to have them surgically removed.
Quote from "heatrn11", >Can i ask you a question? How was the universe formed?
Well, we start with the big bang, where space-time expanded from an infinitely dense and hot point. Just kidding. This is a trick question, whether or not we know how the universe came to be is irrelevant. Scientists and people who do not believe in a religion do not generally claim to know how the universe came to be, and from a naturalistic standpoint we may never have the means to know. But as I said, it's irrelevant, as you yourself cannot claim to know how the universe came to be other than pure speculation that god did it, and in which case I want to refer you to the Carl Sagan quote I posted earlier.
Quote from "Pink Phat", >From an atheist point of view, Satan wll obviously win.
From an atheist point of view, god and satan are made up constructs found within a book and do not exist. However it's obvious that satan would win! Hail satan!
Quote from "Loveandpower", >If a person who does not believe in God states they believe in Satan then they are not a real atheist.
The definition of an atheist is one who is not a theist. The phrase "all babies are atheists" comes about because babies have no knowledge of religion and therefore do not believe it therefore are not theists, so they are atheists. Minor nitpick but I feel the distinction has to be made when we're dealing with people some of whom are under the impression that atheism is a religion.

@The_Un-Named wrote:

Sorry for the late reply, I’ve been a little preoccupied.

[quote=“the elve age, post:17, topic:451479”][quote]Quote from Niall
If you’re going down the “intelligent design” route, could you perhaps explain some problems with the “intelligent design”? Such as humans having a near useless appendix which can burst requiring people to have them surgically removed. Such as people having wisdom teeth that serve no current purpose, which cause people unnecessary pain and also require the person to have them surgically removed.
[/quote]Evolution.[/quote]

I am fully aware that wisdom teeth and the appendix both have previously had a use, but not necessarily as having a modern use. I am also aware that the appendix may have a modern use.

The argument that I was trying to get at is that it isn’t necessarily intelligent to have such examples as wisdom teeth or an appendix, the wisdom teeth currently serve no purpose and many people are required to have them removed, the appendix can be removed without problems, and while very rare it has been known for people to be born without an appendix. The Intelligent Design theory argues that rather than means such as natural selection, an intelligent design proponent is required, hence slapping an Intelligent Design label on evolution does not many any sense, evolution explains the appendix and wisdom teeth while Intelligent Design cannot.

For the record I am not denying evolution, I consider wisdom teeth and the appendix as two of many examples of evolution, I do not consider them examples of Intelligent Design and I do not consider evolution as a catalyst of Intelligent Design.

[quote=“the elve age, post:17, topic:451479”][quote]Quote from Niall
The bible claims that Jesus was born in nazareth, it has been shown through excavations that there is not and has never been a city on the site where nazareth is claimed to be.[/quote]It is speculated that there was no city called Nazareth DURING biblical time periods. Nazareth was started around the 70 CE period (around the time of the First Jewish War). Artifacts have proven it’s existence.[/quote]

That’s contrary to what I heard, that the artefacts found on the supposed site of nazareth suggest the site was unlikely to be a city.

Let me know if you want to revisit this, I’m not particularly in the mood or capable of digging up sources right now.

[quote=“the elve age, post:17, topic:451479”][quote]Quote from Niall
The bible claims plagues in Egypt (and was the bane of my childhood religious classes, seeing that I was interested in Egypt and knew that these claims were nothing more than fictional stories despite being 6), again this is demonstrably false as no evidence or historical records exist barring one book. [/quote]It has been proven that Egypt did experience plagues during the said biblical time period. Archaeologists do believe that the mythical ten plagues occurred in the ancient city of Pi-Ramses and they have uncovered evidence that leaves questions, as to why an entire capital just vanished? Stalagmites in caves have shown weather changes during the period, it is known that the Ramses environment was a warm, wet climate and had a dramatic shift to an incredible drought.[/quote]

I was under the impression that the only evidence archaeologists have found that would “support” the plagues of the bible was an example of how a chain of natural events could explain all the plagues of the bible. I was unaware that this was being proposed as what actually had happened. Again, please let me know if you want to revisit this as I am unable to dig up sources to clarify anything right now.

One thing I want to add however, the context of my original statement was that not everything the bible states is true or has been proven, the other example that I listed (which you neglected to reply to) was that of a global flood. There is no scientific consensus at all that a global flood ever occurred, there is no evidence to suggest that a global flood ever occurred, there is even evidence against a global flood occurring.

[quote=“the elve age, post:17, topic:451479”][quote]Quote from Niall
I want to elaborate something, god kicked humans out of the garden of eden because eve ate the forbidden fruit, however god never gave adam and eve the knowledge of right and wrong, good and bad so while god forbid eve from eating from the tree she wouldn’t have known it was wrong to do so in the first place[/quote]I just read over Genesis 1-3 directly from the bible. The bible never said that when Adam or Eve were created that they had no knowledge of right or wrong, but had no knowledge of good or evil.[/quote]

Semantics, right and wrong, good and evil. I’ll come back to this shortly, I’m a little pressed for time today and want to try to reply to everyone.

the elve age:

My information has been gathered from various reliable sites, personal knowledge, research, and the bible. Some of your questions can be answered by research.

I just want to clarify (and this is no excuse heh) that I haven’t (yet) done any research prior to making a post in this thread, that is, I’m merely posting off of memory and what research I have done before. When I will do research for a post I’ll give sources at the bottom.

heatrn11:

What I am trying to say is that God gave them a choice, he knew the outcome, he knew every single detail, but yet he still gave them a choice.If that’s not love then I don’t know what is…

Not much of a choice though is it? God knew and predestined it to happen, whatever eve did was meaningless since god knew beforehand what the outcome would have been. I’d say if he wanted to show love then he would have changed the outcome, not put the tree in the garden in the first place.

heatrn11:

Not think in your head just this once, that God is real. Wouldn’t you think the death of the millions of humans that he himself created pains him, wouldn’t he hate to let his own ‘children’ go to hell and suffer eternal damnation of unimaginable agony. But God only makes one decision, he never changes his mind, he’s still the same God from the beginning of time, time doesn’t effect him.

I always thought that if god were real he would have to receive some sick and twisted jollies from sending people to hell. One issue I have is that there doesn’t need to be a hell, god could have dropped the whole hell thing and instantly would have been 100 times less evil for doing so, despite being responsible for some sicked up things.

Let me put hell into some perspective, if you do commit a crime in a finite world (earth), you will be punished for an infinite amount of time. You will never, ever stop being punished for this crime. Not only that, the punishment won’t be bad, it won’t be really bad, the punishment you will receive cannot ever be worse. So, for committing a crime you will be punished in the absolute worse way ever for all of eternity. There will never be a time you will not stopped being punished. Worse of all, the crime can be as bad as denying the existence of god.

So, when you say god is all loving I disagree. I say god is all evil for allowing hell to exist. God can remove hell and still leave us on this sick sad world and would merely be a bit of an asshole, instead we’re faced with hell which I think makes god evil.

heatrn11:

Man will keep trying to understand God with no prevail, they’ll keep trying to get ‘physical’ evidence that he exists, to no prevail. But the evidence is right in your face, ‘ya’ know, but I guess you don’t :S.

God is an entity that can never be proven to exist, or proven to not exist. Just like the pink unicorn or the flying spaghetti monster.

heatrn11:

oh yeah one more thing, I don’t have enough [font=arial black]faith[/font] to be an atheist, because to believe that something was created from nothing just requires A LOT of it.

Being an atheist requires absolutely no faith at all. The only requirement of being an atheist, despite popular opinion, is that you do not believe in a god or gods. One could argue that you are in fact an atheist of the Muslim interpretation of the abrahamic god, or of the Jewish interpretation. You’re definitely an atheist of the hindu gods.

Furthermore, “because to believe that something was created from nothing just requires A LOT of it.” is a strawman argument. The big bang theory does not claim that we were created from nothing. It’s a gross misinterpretation of the theory, which I have explained before and do not wish to explain again when I know it won’t be read. If you want to know more though, please press 1. I can dig the post up if you wish.

m1lkman:

God gave an option and people used their own free will not to listen.

That’s not free will though. The problem with such a thing as free will is that knowing that you have free will means you do not have free will. Did they use their free will to not be flooded? Nope. They were forced to go with noah or be flooded, they had a choice but they didn’t have free will in the matter.

One could also argue that if god has the power to know what will happen, then we don’t have free will.

m1lkman:

[quote]But by all accounts in the bible god is not peaceful, take the story of the tower of babel for instance, a united man all speaking one language attempted to build a tower that would reach the heavens, god not wanted any of this gave different groups different languages so they could no longer cooperate. Whether or not you interpret this literally or not, it says something about gods character, he would rather divide (and conqueror) man rather than have man cooperate.

You are correct in say God is not peaceful. God sent the Israelites to wipe out entire nations of people.

I disagree when you say God “divided and conquered” man. In verse 5 and 6 of Genesis 11 we read that God recognized they could do anything as one. I do not know God’s plan but I would like to speculate; God realized if man learned they could do anything as one, they would put themselves on a pedestal equal with God. God knows the heart of man, we read in Jeremiah 17:9 that, “The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked: who can know it?”. God knows that man is proud and boastful. Once Man proclaimed they were equal with God, God would have to destroy him. God didn’t want this, instead he chose to give each man a separate tongue.[/quote]

I’m not quite sure what there is to disagree on, perhaps you can elaborate it. Humans under a common language cooperated to build a tower to the heavens, god divided them by separating them to the corners of the earth and giving them a separate tongue so they could no longer cooperate, effectively conquering their plans.

But the whole story is hypothetical, one of my favourite quotes often attributed to Yuri Gagarin, - “I see no God up here”. We’ve flown to the top of the clouds. We’ve exited Earth’s atmosphere into space. We’ve stepped foot on the moon. We’ve sent probes to Mars. We’ve had man made objects (nearly) exit the solar system. If there is a god, he doesn’t exist within our universe.

m1lkman:

[quote]Would now be a good time to remind you that other people who read and follow the bible don’t believe in the son or holy spirit? There’s several thousand sects of christianity because people who read and follow the bible can’t make up how the bible should be interpreted. Divine word of god? Then why can’t the followers decide on what should be and what shouldn’t be followed.

If you follow the Bible then you must believe in Jesus Christ (the son). That is a fact, otherwise you are not a Christian. When Christ was baptized by John the Baptist what happened? God came down in the form of a dove and said, “This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.”

In John 4 23-24 Jesus says, “But the hour cometh, and now is, when the true worshippers shall worship the Father in spirit and in truth: for the Father seeketh such to worship him. God is a Spirit: and they that worship him must worship him in spirit and in truth.” KJV[/quote]

Arguably at least but that isn’t what I said. A definition of a christian is one who believes in the bible and follows the teachings of christ, and as such I consider anyone who believes in the christian god and follows the teachings of christ to be a christian, they don’t necessarily have to believe in jesus or that he existed.

The point I was getting at is that there are several thousand sects of christianity because they believe different things. You can be a christian and not believe in heaven or hell, you can be a christian and believe in heaven and hell. You can be a christian and not follow the 10 commandments, you can be a christian and not believe in angels etc. Christianity is merely a label that simplifies things, anyone remember the catholic-protestant war? If you guys went back to being catholics or protestants or whatever sect you belong to then there would be no unifying belief anymore.

m1lkman:

[quote]It’s not a choice though, is it? Do as I say or face eternal damnation of unimaginable agony. That’s like a rapist telling his victim “don’t fight or I will stab you”. I won’t even bring up the idea of free will, either.

It is a choice. God gave us free will to decide what we want. Why did he give us free will, why not just make robots? God only knows. We read in Matthew 7 13 and 14, Jesus says, “Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat: Because strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, which leadeth unto life, and few there be that find it.”

The Father works in all of our hearts. He gives every single man, woman, and child an option to accept eternal life and many reject him.[/quote]

It’s really not a choice though, is it? Choose between eternal happiness or eternal hellfire, either way you will live in the afterlife for all eternity. What if someone doesn’t want to live in all eternity? They have no choice in the matter, no free will regarding that.

It’s semantics but I feel it’s important, it’s not free will if you’re being forced to pick between either outcome when other options are available.

m1lkman:

[quote]The bible claims that Jesus was born in nazareth, it has been shown through excavations that there is not and has never been a city on the site where nazareth is claimed to be.

Jesus was born in Bethlehem but I’m sure that was an honest mistake on your part.

God hasn’t shown himself to people because faith cometh by hearing and hearing by the Word of God. I think I’ll just quote the whole of Hebrews 11;

There will come a day when people will accept a man for performing great works: making statues come to life, make fire come down from heaven, etc. People will be amazed and worship him. That man will be the AntiChrist[/quote]

Jesus being born in nazareth was a mistake, he was of course born in bethlehem as you corrected me and was mainly raised in nazareth.

But of course you say god hasn’t shown himself, if you go back and read what I was replying to you can see that heatrn11 has claimed that god has shown himself! Funny how you two can believe in the same thing but not the same thing!

I am of course content with there being no evidence of god not showing himself because he doesn’t choose to or because he doesn’t exist, it’s one of many reasons why I am an atheist. I cannot accept the idea of a god on faith alone.

m1lkman:

[quote]Pure speculation on your part. To quote Carl Sagan, “In many cultures it is customary to answer that God created the universe out of nothing. But this is mere temporizing. If we wish courageously to pursue the question, we must, of course ask next where God comes from? And if we decide this to be unanswerable, why not save a step and conclude that the universe has always existed?”.

Just to quote the Bible on this one;

[quote=John 1: 1-3]n the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

2 The same was in the beginning with God.

3 All things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made that was made.[/quote]
Edit: Had to change the last quote up a little bit.[/quote]

That would of course be unanswerable, the bible says god exists, and the only evidence for this is the bible. The bible is the claim of gods existence, it is not the proof.

m1lkman:

I enjoy these conversations Niall.

Likewise.

[quote=“Mitko, post:23, topic:451479”][quote author=Niall link=topic=554363.msg4060272#msg4060272 date=1343349896]

[quote]Quote from “heatrn11”,

To tell you the reason why God hasn’t proven himself to Earth, is that, God has actually revealed himself in the past.[/quote]
and knew that these claims were nothing more than fictional stories despite being 6), again this is demonstrably false as no evidence or historical records exist barring one book. There’s dozens of other things in the bible that are contradictory or have been proven false
[/quote]
http://articles.latimes.com/2012/may/23/science/la-sci-sn-bethlehem-seal-20120523
http://articles.latimes.com/2004/dec/26/news/adfg-izpool26

Just wanted to point that out.[/quote]

I’ll come back to this later, but a news paper article? That’s a bit of a stretch for a credible source, and not the only stretch I can see.

Israeli archaeologists digging near the city of Jerusalem have discovered an ancient clay bulla, about 2,700 years old, bearing the name Bethlehem. The artifact is the only known ancient reference to the city of Jesus' birth found outside the Bible, experts said. The find shows not only that the city existed, but that it probably also had a thriving commercial trade.

Archaeologists discover a clay bulla with a name on it, and that is evidence of a city? You would think the remains of the city would be evidence.

and hooooooooly raptor jesus, if only double posting was permitted then I could have broken this post down into manageable chunks

@Loveandpower wrote:

The definition of an atheist is one who is not a theist. The phrase "all babies are atheists" comes about because babies have no knowledge of religion and therefore do not believe it therefore are not theists, so they are atheists.

Minor nitpick but I feel the distinction has to be made when we’re dealing with people some of whom are under the impression that atheism is a religion.

I can see where your coming from but I still look at it in the sense that the classification itself about what an atheist believes in. Most people who say they do not believe in heaven claim to be atheist.

How can you believe in one part of the “fanatical world” and not the other.
